commentBody:
I found this very clever and very gentle start to a new year of Sunday puzzles. BASE PAIRS indeed. No cross words for this one, please.
Thanks, Gene.

This was great fun; love the themed entries. I wonder how long it‚Äôs been since we last saw 44-down in a Times puzzle? It seems like the kind of word that constructors would love to use, but I can‚Äôt recall seeing it.

Early and wrong idea of a theme: I filled in JUDAS at 69D, and noted that two of those letters (U and A) are bases in DNA/RNA.
Aha, sez I, we‚Äôre supposed to swap those letters for their partner in the base pair! And those new letters will make the across entries work.

Wrong theme conjecture = extra fun, in my book.  Later on I said ‚Äúoh *that* kind of base‚Äù!

Anyhow: all you constructors wanting to do a nucleic acid theme - I‚Äôll be ready!

One of the most creative ones yet‚Ä¶didn‚Äôt get the clue till after it was done though I saw bits and pieces throughout. Once I finished, it was like, ohhhhh! First time poster. Had to because it was so good!

Fantastic puzzle with crisp execution! Hats off to the constructor.

Now I eagerly await the commentary of the anti Thursday / Sunday crossword purist coalition ;-)

Wow, I love the DOUBLE CROSSED theme and the break from crossword convention. When I came across the first set of repeating entries I thought for sure I had an error, but then I noticed the two IAGOs crossing OTHELLO  and the lightbulb went on.  

Very impressive construction! It‚Äôs easy enough to come up with a second clue for SCAR and SET, but not so easy for JUDAS, BRUTUS and IAGO. 

Not a ton of wordplay, but I especially like [Where idols go head-to-head] for TOTEM and [Paired chips with dips] for RHYMED. 

Thanks, Gene Louise, that was fun!
Loved this! In a meta sense this puzzle slyly double crossed the 'no doubles' protocol lol
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2026/01/03/sunday-january-4-2025/#ny

I really enjoyed this puzzle, but broke my streak because I got stuck thinking DOUBLECROSSES or DOUBLECROSSER and couldn‚Äôt figure out that HADST was the word I needed.

Still had lots of fun wih this one!
üòÖ had _EN__ for 46 Down. I am not 12. I am not male. Still had a little giggle.
RAPINE was apt given today's headlines (and for US foreign policy in general as well)

m-yech.

The double crosses were fine...Too many words where an internet search was used to complete the puzzle.  (or worse a crossword making app)
Spent two weeks in Bishkek in the late 90s.  Can't imagine what it's like now.

Clever cluing, double fun.  JUDAS was a double crosser, and IAGO was too, and when I remembered the title of the puzzle, I was off and running.  But so many clues pointed in so many directions, most of which didn't fit, and made Gene Louise a sly double crosser too.  SINTER was new to me, and so was RAPINE, but they were unshakeable when the crosses were so solid. Resourceful, I'd say.

What I'd call a dazzler, and an entertaining one at that.  Thank you, Gene Louise, for a needed distraction on this fraught day.

Well, that was lots of fun!! Figuring out the theme brought a lovely amount of glee this solver! 

Had a little trouble in the lower right... the whole area under POPSUGAR, which I'd not heard of, was my big slowdown. Too bad I'm not a bigger lotr person‚ÄîI envy those of you who found GALADRIEL to be a gimme. I needed every single cross to get her name. And I had some wrong entries there, like BEGaT instead of BEGOT, which made it very hard for me to think of GOOSEEGG. Fortunately, there were a few gimmes down there, like OTHELLO and the DOUBLECROSSing IAGOs, so I got there in just over average time. What a fun theme!! 

Really enjoyed STOPITYOUTWO, RHYMED, and LATEBLOOMERS.

Fun Sunday!

Brilliant theme and so elegant.  As @Eric Hougland writes in his Crossword Fiend review (see link in his comment), the theme was both fun and high-brow, no easy feat.  I love Sundays with layers and this one was as richly layered as an entremet.  And learning a few new words (SINTER, RAPINE) always makes me happy ‚Äî AIT‚Äôs never too late for us LATE BLOOMERS.
This was excellent! Lots of fun. Loved the non-themed stuff as well. Thank you, Gene Louise! Just a delightful puzzle. Y‚Äôall have a great Sunday!
I love how the puzzle doublecrossed me by making me doubt duplicate answers. What a delightfully devious thing to do. Marvelous theme elegantly presented. I'd like to request seconds, please.

This is one of those cases where being a computer scientist probably hurt my solve when it came to technical clues. I wrote ‚Äúc SHARP‚Äù in for 66D immediately, and only switched to F SHARP when the music didn‚Äôt play and ‚ÄúcILCHES‚Äù looked odd. (Though to be fair, I‚Äôve also never heard of FILCHES)

Not saying F# isn‚Äôt a valid language! Just saying as a tech guy who has written mostly object oriented stuff, I leapt to an answer out of cockiness.

I thought for sure this was going to be DNA related based on the title AND the constructor‚Äôs first name. My first clue as to what was going on was seeing SCAR as my answer twice and scratching my head thinking this can‚Äôt be right?!  Then it happened again with BRUTUS and I was off to the races. I did have RAPINE ending with a g initially (I was thinking of it in relation to pillaging). But IGNORES cured me of that. I just really enjoyed this entire grid. Thank you Gene Louise. This truly brightened my evening as I recover from the flu.

I had DOGE BRO for obnoxious fratty sort. It'll be a thing soon, I promise you. 

Funny how ALIT can be both [Got off] and [Got on].

I still remember how Thomas Haden Church's character quietly betrays Paul Giamatti's character in that movie "Sideways." What a good film that was.

Lovely, rich vocabulary here: FILCHES, SINTER, PLACATES, GOOSE EGG (plus FRY UP, haha), and I could go on. I didn't find this as easy as some did, possibly distracted by current threats to that Athenian invention mentioned in this puzzle from BUBBA and his DOGE BROS, may he dine well on all that nitrate-laden fare, and if he HAS A BEEF hamburger with chips, dips and pop sugar, then asks what's on the sub menu, well bless the heart that beats within his sturdy ribcage!

Et TWO Brute?

I was not SCARred by this puzzle and it did not lay a GOOSEEGG (at one point all I had on that one were the EEGG, which was a bit of a head scratcher).  I did a double take when I saw the second BRUTUS, but didn‚Äôt catch on to the multiple doubling until I saw the two JUDASes.  It took me a little longer to spot that the double crossers double crossed their victims.  A nice layered reveal.  

Any puzzle with GALADRIEL clued as the splendid Cate Blanchett is a winner in my book.

Where idols go head to head: TOTEM. Pure gold.
that was fun,  38 minutes
Love that the constructor fit in STOPITYOUTWO,  directed at those doubled double-crossers, no doubt :-)

Very unusual and well executed theme. Missed it with SET but was wondering what was going wrong in my brain with BRUTUS and this Ohio guy wasn‚Äôt going to miss the Ohio State mascot. I really loved the cute LATEBLOOMERS clue over the educational SIERRALEONE entry at the the end.
A lot of fun.

An observation on 116A, and language variation. Right now I‚Äôm sitting watching Australia play England at cricket where, as a score of [zero] is a ‚Äúduck‚Äù (egg), so GOOSEEGG did not come readily to mind.

Very enjoyable and more challenging than some recent Sundays. I filled the entire grid (I print it out) but had only noticed three of the "base pairs" so I hunted around for the other two (OSIRIS/SET and MUFAS/SCAR)--how could I have not registered those duplications the way I did when I came across the two BRUTUSES (Bruti?). Anyway, even without italics (printed and ink saver mode), I dug down and got there with my pink highlighter to show the double crosses. Bravo, Gene!

So clearly the new trend (standard?) is for Sundays to be the hardest day of the week?  'Cause not even counting last week's magician's paint-on-top-of-paint, the Sundays lately have been significantly harder than Saturday or Friday.  For me anyhow.

Anyway..... This was an interestingly crafted puzzle though I can't say I really enjoyed it.  Two ses in "pluses" and "sgtmaj" and "aslant" all kind of annoyed me.  Got off doesn't seem to fit "alit".

I'm sure others liked it a lot more than I did though.  A respectable and challenging puzzle overall.  The theme was all right.

Oh, that‚Äôs one terrific theme.  The marvelous cast of Othello, Jesus, Musafa, Osiris, and Caesar ‚Äì all who were double-crossed ‚Äì being visually double-crossed by their double-crossers in the grid.

Pure originality ‚Äì how often do you see a theme like that?  Furthermore, IMO, the theme was beautified by those artfully-written italicized clues describing the villainous characters.

Then, the skill and talent behind making this.  Designing a symmetrical grid to accommodate five sets of three answers plus a 13-letter revealer had to be a bear.  

Meanwhile, witty clues, such as [Building that shouldn‚Äôt have running water] for ICE PALACE, and [Paired chips with dips?] for RHYMED, brightened the way, as did the gorgeous FILCHES bannering the center of the box.  My wheelhouse deficiencies provided trouble spots here and there, happifying my work-loving brain.

The art and science of crosswords showcased in your quality creation, Gene.  Thank you, sir, and bravo!
Very clever puzzle, love the theme.
Big shout to SESAME PLACE, our favorite family vacation. The kids aged out of it too quickly, but my wife and I would gladly recommend.
So clever ‚Äî kudos!
For whatever reason, Sunday is generally the crossword day I enjoy the least, but I thought this one was outstanding and well worth the bit of inevitable crosswordese in the grid. Thanks!

Ruh-ROH, Astro and PINENUTS and Red ADAIR. What's not to love? 
I confess that I was so intent on solving I didn't notice the double answers. I think solving on the phone app contributed to that a bit. It's a bit harder to take in the entire puzzle at the same time. A good start for the new Sunday puzzling year.

Et tu, Sunday!
Boy howdy, THAT was worth the doublecross.

"I will wear my loss upon my sleeve 
For emus to peck at: I am not what I am." 

Now off to sleep, perchance to dream of squares filled and unfulfilled, with a sigh, "Farewell the tranquil mind! Farewell content!"

Somewhere, there's a steel-rimmed hat spinning in space . . .


Do you expect me to gawk?

No, I expect you to fry.

fiendish in all the best ways for a grid.
thank you, sir.
The clue for 98 down, ‚ÄúLead-in to Tech‚Äù should have been ‚ÄúLead-in to tech‚Äù. The school it is referring to is Caltech, not CalTech or Cal Tech.
Of all the days to work 118A, KIDNAP, into the grid!!

What did I miss on FSharp? Know about C, C++, and Csharp, and also pilfering, which in my tired mind I thought was Pilcher. I had to Auto-check to finish this one which broke my 9-day Auric streak. . .
When I entered 91A, I thought to myself, "Please, oh, please...I hope we don't invite backlash criticism by complaining about this one.

What a fun one! But stymied by the fact that I'm 32 and still can't remember that sesame is sesame and not seseme, guess I didn't watch enough Sesame Street! 

Belated very happy retirement to Deb!

Surely as this is a column on language and usage it wouldn't be out of line to ask if the columnist and editors intended to stay that Caesar and his army *forded* the Rubicon, rather than "forging" it?
Why is the puzzle info page now white in dark mode??? (On Android) It used to be black, and makes the experience much less pleasant.

I can say with great confidence that this is my favorite puzzle so far this year ;)

Seriously though, what a clever and well-executed theme!

Not a bad theme but I had to look up some stuff to finish and in the end I needed to check the puzzle - but that's standard for me on Sundays, when I CBA to flyspeck the huge grid.

RAPINE and SINTER... ü§∑üèΩ

I've never seen "The Lion King", but I must have picked up SCAR somewhere because I was able to enter that, with a few crosses. I haven't read or seen "Othello", either. I have blindspots both in high and popular culture ü§£

Sometimes a puzzles drives so far up my alley it almost dents my garage door. 

[smiles happily]

Well, hello there, Gene.

I enjoyed solving. But, as far as I was concerned, the theme just made it easier, not more fun  I knew SET and OSIRIS right away, and had both of the former, so saw that duplicated answers were allowed today. 

I didn‚Äôt notice that the duplicate answers crossed the relevant names. That was clever, after reading the column.
Good puzzle but can anyone explain AIT? British isle??
DOUBLE CROSS and double stack of TWOs in NE corner! With TO serving as a hinge.

For the website devs, I've previewed the update designed to "improve how you see replies to posts" and I can officially provide my feedback. It has worsened how I see replies to posts!

Replies to replies are now nested and much more difficult to spot, requiring extra clicks to un-nest (there's a new word for you, setters).

Works fine as it is, methinks - it's pretty obvious from the @s at the start of a message who the message is directed at. And much nicer to just read all of the replies in one flat list. Just my two cents!

Anyone else agree with me?

Clever puzzle, but one of the hardest Sundays I‚Äôve done in a while. Between the words I‚Äôd never seen before (SINTER, RAPINE, NO CAP), the answers I was sure were right but weren‚Äôt (C SHARP), the answers I was sure were wrong but were right (ALIT), and the names I simply didn‚Äôt know (GALADRIEL, the parrot IAGO), this was a slow journey. But still a good one.

I must admit, entering that second BRUTUS felt all kinds of wrong‚Äî but also IMPishly right. Sometimes it‚Äôs fun to break rules.

I have two thoughts:

1)
It seems like we've seen NO CAP in the last year or so, but I can't remember it precisely.  So I'm kind of embarrassed to say that I'm embarrassed that I forgot it, because I have not have forgotten.

As I used to say, my memory is so good these days that I can remember things that never happened.

2)
Now I've forgotten the second thought.  If it comes back, I may put it in a reply to myself.

Oh, wait, I got it.  So ALIT is yet another contronym.  I'm thinking of only using contronyms from now on when speaking or writing.  That way I'll always be sure to be right.

ü§©My name in print, this makes people. I feel like Naven Johnson when he found his name listed in the phone book; if you get what I‚Äôm saying. I‚Äôd shout it from the rooftop but ‚Äòtis too icy plus  I have a case of acrophobia.

This was a really great grid. Solid theme with good theme entries, interesting and fun fill, and a lot of hard trivia but all the answers were mostly gettable through crosses (with a couple of forgivable exceptions). Amazing work! Looking forward to more from the setter.
Duplicitous.

A good crossword teaches me something I didn't know before:

44D/48A: "AIT" was a new word for me, and lookled so odd, I wondered if it was a British initialism (A.I.T.) for something "islandy." But no, it's just riverine island. I'm surprised it hasn't entered the Dictionary of Crosswordese.
But "ALIT"--the clue seemed off to me. Turns out, I had the general notion of "alight" correct--the idea of moving from a high surface to a lower one--but missed the point that the focus was (moving off) the higher one, not (onto) the lower. Which only makes sense as one "lightens" the (horse's, etc.) load when you "alight" from it.

Off clue, however, 79D: while, in conventional, modern music typography, quarter- and eighth-rests are certainly squiggly, whole- and half-rests are about as *un*-squiggly as one can get--basically plain black rectangles which sit above (half) or hang below (whole) a staff line. ("The boat floats on top of the water because it is only half-full, but sinks below it because it is completely full.")

Wow - so many  interesting words, as many have said before me. I was happy to learn some new things - GOOSE EGG rather than duck, MAUD, SINTER, RAPINE, PIPET, not pipette, ALAI, CASABA, all through crosses. Clever construction too, with those doubles. 

I'm really amazed though, that people remember the name of a parrot in a cartoon from 1992 (I looked it up). Can that sneak in as trivia? 

Very enjoyable.
The kid stuff did me in: SESAMEPLACE and MUFASA.  Never heard of either one. Also, RAPINE. What the?
Had sLOEGin as the ‚Äúsoothing goo‚Äù  figuring it was some old-timey nightclub slang.
Much too clever and tricky in my opinion.  I'm good at words but not at clever tricks.  This puzzle was not fun and not fair.

It‚Äôs a good puzzle when you need to put the puzzle down once to clear the cobwebs.  It‚Äôs a great puzzle when you need to sleep on it before error checking. 

Very clever! Good start to the new year!

Tough Sunday...
Guessing that FILCHES purposely crossed DOUBLECROSS in the center? Or maybe the theme just made me want to look for something more devious than the theme itself
"Not gonna lie. . ." is NO nAP.  I don't get the correct answer yet.
Not happy with 103 across.  NYC is a legit abbreviation for New York City, but NYS for New York State?
This puzzle made me feel a bit double crossed. And was way over my weary brain. Brutus clue helped a bit.
A brick home can be adobe? Someone left reality on that one. Irritating puzzle.

GOOSEEGG took way too long to incubate, because somehow I forgat one of the past tenses of ‚Äúbeget‚Äù.

This was a good, fun Sunday puzzle, with all its 363 double crossings.
Woof‚Äîlots of blanks until the switch finally went on in my brain. Really good puzzle.

I thoroughly enjoyed this solve, contrary to the naysayers in some of the previous comments‚Ä¶
Excellent theme, interesting and varied fill, what‚Äôs not to love?!

One thing that currently eludes me however‚Ä¶ Caitlin Lovinger mentions the significance of ‚ÄòSet‚Äô crossing ‚ÄòOsiris‚Äô at its ‚Äòsecond and final‚Äô letter, as well as mentioning how ‚ÄòBrutus‚Äô twice crosses ‚ÄòCaesar‚Äô at the ‚ÄòS‚Äô and the ‚ÄòR‚Äô‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt yet spot the link or the significance of either of these so if anyone can help me out please do!

Still trying to figure out where I filled a square in wrong, but it's a very clever theme today (and I noted the two little Greek crosses in the grid as well). Is there a punny association of OTHELLO, MUFASA and OSIRIS with crosses in some sense not pertaining to the crossword itself and not in the sense of being double-crossed? That's what I expected after I got JUDAS/JESUS and BRUTUS/CAESAR. Obviously Caesar crossed the Rubicon, as is mentioned in the clue, and Jesus died on a cross.

The revealer made this puzzle for me. I had noticed the duplicate entries and gotten the gist of what was going on (aided by the title), but was still skeptical of the theme until I got DOUBLE CROSSED ‚Äî and a big smile came across my face.

I found the puzzle a tad more difficult than most Sunday entries.  The device used was fine with me and I admit to not knowing a number of the less well known more modern terms.  That‚Äôs all fine,  what I do have a problem with is all of the proper names in the fill.  Just too many for my taste.

What a great Sunday grid, exactly what I look for; tough, tricky, head scratching, with a real Aha revealer. 
Seeing duplicated clues really helped me find the theme and what a good one. Well done to Gene Louise.
Save yourself the trouble and just google the many MANY totally obscure proper nouns. Why not? The constructor obviously did.

Using the same answer twice, even as a themed entry, just felt wrong. I don‚Äôt recall doing any crosswords prior to this where a single answer was repeated, let alone five or six times. I guess it felt confining and confusing to me, which made it difficult and unfamiliar, even for a Sunday themed puzzle.

That and the sprinkling of genuinely challenging entries, (yes, SINTER, RAPINE and FSHARP but also the seemingly benign SGTMAJ, AURIC, PISH and AIT / ACRES / ALIT) made this a slow grind.

I needed to proof it a couple of times before getting it past the gold star review, finally catching AVON / PAVE after fixing PAOLO / TELOS / MAUNA LOA.

Kudos

Whew. And Wow. Good long workout for me and must confess that I was not grasping the theme at all until I was almost done and just stopped and pondered for a bit. No big deal - just made for a nice 'aha' moment at the end. 

And... I'll put today's rather amazing puzzle find in a reply. 

....
6 minutes over my Sunday average, but very proud of myself to have done it!
A good example of why the "rules" are not absolute. Very creative, challenging and enjoyable to solve.

Well, this thing is just too dang big.  
I read the clue for 1A and instantly thought PERICARDIUM ...which is absolutely correct but not the entry....so, PFFT.
...aside from which, the RIBCAGE leaves a lot to be desired as protection, given that a stiletto can be inserted handily and bingo! The End.  

Add in a big dose of Disney (will the fake-o cartoon characterizations never end??) and anachronisms (Julius wasn't CAESAR when he made his horse wade into the Rubicon) and PISH without the TOSH...this ole lady HADST enough.  

BUBBA didn't do HiHoState much good in that game, did he?

Maybe I can come back and read the Comments later when I cool down.
Excellent puzzle!  I didn‚Äôt catch on to the DOUBLE CROSSErs crossing the DOUBLE CROSSEes while I was solving, so I‚Äôm glad Caitlin pointed that out in her column.

Admission:  I have always disliked Sylvia Plath, even though admittedly, she's never done anything to me.

Eschewing all the structured walls
Of meter and of rhyme, 
Of rhythm and sonority
That other poets climb,

You call your craft "tyrannical"
And think yourself a Bard,
But rhyme's what makes it hard, Ms. Plath --
Yes, rhyme's what makes it hard.

When rhyme's not there, said Robert Frost --
And here I'd like to quote:
It's tennis played without a net --
Yes, that is what he wrote!

Is poetry "tyrannical"?
I think, Ms. Plath, that's true.
But truest for the Bards who rhyme
And not so much for you.
This was fun, especially after I clocked that the double-crosser and double-crossed were connected. Thanks!
I would‚Äôve voted for BUCKY MCBUCKFACE.

I first learned about BRUTUS from Shakespeare's JULius CAESAR, and viewed him as a figure who had to make an extraordinarily difficult decision:  loyalty to Republic over loyalty to a MENTOR.  
So, more of a hero than a DOUBLE-CROSSEr.

I remember when later in life, when I first read Dante's "Inferno", being shocked that the Italian POET condemned BRUTUS to be eternally chewed on in the mouth of Satan, along with his co-conspirator Cassius and JUDAS, as the greatest sinners in the history of humanity!

The most satisfying solve in recent memory.  Very impressive theme execution!

ALSO: A plethora of proper nouns is so much better than multiple clues qualified by "in modern slang"...IMO, SMH, LOL.
I had CSHARP for so long
Spent forever trying to fix answers that were correct (MAUD, NOCAP, AIT).  Turns out I was DOUBLECROSSED by "DOUBLECROSSEs."  Going to blame my high school German for thinking that HAsST was correct.

Took a LONG while to wrap my head around the idea that it was OK to have duplicate answers - still not crazy about it.

As a computer programmer of long experience i was willing to go along with C SHARP, Microsoft's try at a proprietary programming language , but F SHARP? Never heard of it. A little too out there for me. 

Didn't like SINTER,  didn't get AIT for a British isle, and got most of the puzzle through the crossing, bless them. 

Not a fan of this one. Moving on

Howdy :)

I really enjoyed this Sunday! For cause of the fact that I am 13, I did ask my Dad for some help with this one, as I normally do with Fridays and Saturdays as well XD


Spoiler alert.

Anywho, when I saw the clue I put CSHARP but the other clues revealed that it was indeed, FSHARP. When I out that one down I knew I had a 5050 chance of getting it right, but also that there is probably another less common _SHARP language out there that I didn‚Äôt know about. 
I love programming and developing different things, websites, apps, etc. I have a lot to figure out yet, but I‚Äôm trying :)

Have a lovely Sunday!

Blessingsü´∂
Loved it! What a fun puzzle though, I must say, it took me a surprisingly long time to hit the theme. Thanks!!
Not my favorite Sunday Solve
Brilliant theme! A delightful solve. Enjoyed every moment of it.

One more puzzle find. A Wednesday from June 10, 2009 by Richard Silvestri. Four theme clues and answers: Element number 55-across: RUTHENIUM Atlanta Brave who wore number 55-across: HANKAARON President number 55-across: BARACKOBAMA Feb. 7, 2010 the date of this event's number 55-across: SUPERBOWL And, the reveal... 55A: FOURTYFOUR Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/10/2009&g=35&d=A ....

I can hardly believe I solved it without any help. Once I got the "unwritten rule" issue sorted out it became much easier.
So many unknowns filled in with their crosses, and I'm still trying to figure where AIT fits for British isle.

This solved like a rather tough themeless puzzle with the quirk that some answers were repeated.  I'm all in favor of tougher Sunday puzzles like this one, that result in prolonging the fun!

I confess that I did not grasp the point of the repeated answers while solving. (I kinda thought that NYT crosswords needed to conform to NYT style, and I just saw the spelling PLUSES in the paper very recently, so was surprised to see A PLUSSES here.)

Which double-crossing is literal, and which figurative? Sure, the double-base names in our puzzle are literally ‚Äúcrossing‚Äù their victim‚Äôs name twice. And when I betray my friend, we need not meet at an angle - it is figurative language. 

But also, all the betrayals occur in literature (of one sort or another, just in case someone from a Bible camp suggests otherwise regarding Judas and Jesus), and literary ‚Äúletters‚Äù is at least related etymology to ‚Äòliteral‚Äô. And each double-right-angled crossing: well, we had to ‚Äòfigure it‚Äô out!

BRUTUS and BRUTUS were both sure solves for me, and clued me in on the theme of double entries. JUDAS and JUDAS got me to the more specific theme of betrayers, but it wasn't until MUFASA that I figured out that the betrayed were also included. 21:45 for me today, about 10 minutes below my Sunday average. It was a very enjoyable solve with the theme slowly revealing itself. 
Too bad CYPHER couldn't have been worked in with NEO, but I'm sure the unusual spelling would not have led to a good double entry.
Puzzles like this are jaw-droppingly clever and huge fun. Thanks Gene!
When the "Congratulations!" popped up, i was quite surprised.  Not the funnest Sunday puzzle...by far...but not the worst. Just lacked that elusive je ne sais quoi crossword-y delight. Por moi.

Yes! An unwritten rule in crossword puzzle land, beautifully broken. I loved that the revealer was in the Down clues so that I had been through the grid once before getting to it.

Through the years, I have seen a similar convention in other types of puzzles that have unwritten rules and then break them: whenever you are going to do so, you have to signal in some way that this is what you are doing, and have a plausible, thematic reason.

This puzzle started off very soberly and ended as a delight.
Ugh this was just so not fun ‚Ä¶ can‚Äôt wait till Monday :(
Clever and diabolical! A very fun solve.
So many baked in errors. I kept fixing one by one, but there was always one (or more) out there. Time for a walk!!!!

Not sure what happened to my original post. Oh well, I will PUSH ON.

When I was a student at OSU, there was a comic strip in The Lantern, called "Potshots." It was a bit like "Doonesbury," and very funny. One of the characters was Cletus Buckeye, BRUTUS' evil twin brother. You see, his spiky rind never fell off, and he dressed all in black leather, with metal studs. Memorably, he was arrested for throwing a folding chair at Indiana's Bobby Knight. Ah, memories!
Theme was fun. Fill was not.

And... another late puzzle find. A Sunday from September 2, 1990 by Frances Hansen with the title: "Labor day largess." A couple of theme clue and answer examples: "Baker's largess:" TONSOFBUNS "Madison avenue worker's largess:" SCADSOFADS And.. all of the other theme answers had 'largess' as part of the clue. Some of those answers: HEAPSOFJEEPS PILESOFTILES LOTSOFWATTS SLEWSOFYEWS STACKSOFFLAX FLOODSOFSUDS BAGSOFRAGS GOBSOFCOBS Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=9/2/1990&g=42&d=A ....

I forgot to ask:

@MOL "Julius wasn't CAESAR when he made his horse wade into the Rubicon."

Actually, he was. 
"Caesar" was a cognomen, shared by all, or many, members of the "Caesarean" branch of the Julian family--the first to sport it was one Sextus Julius Caesar, great-great-grandfather of the river-forder. It may have originally meant "hairy," although GJC was anything but.
Subsequent emperors adopted the name "Caesar": at first, it was as a sign of adoptive inheritance (Augustus); but gradually it developed into an abstract title--thence to "Tsar" and "Kaiser," etc.
